high_relevance.description: Learning theory emphasizing how newcomers become integrated into communities of practice through gradually increasing participation
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ1 by theorizing the trajectory from novice to core participation, and RQ2 by identifying mechanisms that facilitate this transition
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Could model participation gradients, legitimate access points, and boundary crossing mechanisms between stocks
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Operationalizing LPP in OSS context with quantitative SD modeling

high_relevance.description: Explains how newcomers learn values, abilities, and behaviors to participate as organizational members
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Addresses RQ1 socialization process and RQ2 interventions for effective onboarding
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Could model socialization tactics, information seeking behaviors, and socialization outcomes
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Applying organizational theory to distributed, voluntary OSS contexts

high_relevance.description: Organization's ability to recognize, assimilate, and apply new knowledge
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Addresses RQ2 knowledge transfer interventions and RQ3 vulnerability prevention through knowledge absorption
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Could model prior knowledge base, knowledge recognition, assimilation, and application rates
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Measuring absorptive capacity at individual and community levels in OSS

adjacent_opportunities.description: Artifacts that enable coordination across different social worlds while maintaining their integrity within each
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Focuses on artifacts rather than people, but crucial for coordination in distributed work
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Examines how documentation, code, and tools facilitate transitions between contributor levels
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Identifying boundary objects that enable periphery-to-core transitions in OSS

adjacent_opportunities.description: Psychological theory explaining how perceived competence drives motivation and persistence
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Shifts focus from community structures to individual psychological factors
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Explains why some developers persist through difficult transitions while others drop out
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Integrating motivational psychology with community participation models

adjacent_opportunities.description: Knowledge that is difficult to transfer through writing or verbalization
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Complements SECI model but focuses specifically on hard-to-codify knowledge
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Addresses the critical challenge of transferring architectural knowledge and code intuition
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Modeling tacit knowledge flows in distributed software development

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: OSS communities as ecosystems with pioneer species, climax communities, and succession patterns
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Modeling community maturation, niche specialization, and resilience to disturbance
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Provides powerful metaphors for understanding community evolution and vulnerability points during transitions

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Learning through guided experience, modeling, coaching, and fading
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Structured approaches to mentorship and skill development in distributed settings
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Offers evidence-based pedagogical strategies that could revolutionize OSS onboarding

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Organizations that operate under hazardous conditions but experience fewer than expected accidents
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Principles for maintaining system reliability during personnel transitions
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Directly addresses RQ3 by providing proven strategies for preventing system failures during turnover

phd_strategy.rationale: LPP provides the core theoretical foundation for the periphery-to-core transition, Absorptive Capacity addresses critical knowledge management challenges, and Boundary Objects offers a novel perspective on coordination artifacts
phd_strategy.integration_strategy: Use LPP as the overarching framework, with Absorptive Capacity modeling knowledge flows and Boundary Objects explaining coordination mechanisms. Integrate with existing Communities of Practice theory for a comprehensive view.
phd_strategy.expected_impact: This combination enables modeling both social participation structures and knowledge flows, addressing all three research questions with theoretical depth while maintaining empirical tractability
